problem.tex: Let $f$ be an entire function and suppose there is a constant $M$, an $R>0$, and a natural number $n$ such that $|f(z)|\leq M|z|^n$ for all $|z|>R$. Show $f$ is a polynomial of degree no more than $n$.

solution.tex: Write $f$ as its Maclauren series, \[f(z)=\sum_{k=0}^\infty\frac{f^{(k)}(0)}{k!}z^k.\] We will estimate the terms $\frac{f^{(k)}(0)}{k!}$ using Cauchy's integral formula. That formula is that \[\frac{f^{(k)}(0)}{k!}=2\pi i\int_\gamma\frac{f(z)}{z^{k+1}}dz\] where $\gamma$ is the circle of radius $R>0$. Then we can perform the estimate \[\left|\frac{f^{(k)}(0)}{k!}\right|=2\pi\left|\int_\gamma\frac{f(z)}{z^{k+1}}dz\right|\leq2\pi\int_\gamma\frac{|f(z)|}{R^{k+1}}|dz|\] \[\leq2\pi\int_\gamma\frac{MR^n}{R^{k+1}}|dz|=\frac{4M\pi^2}{R^{k-n}}.\] For any $k>n$, this will go to $0$ as $R\to\infty$ (this is where we use that $f$ is entire). That means all coefficients in the power series above $n$ vanish, so $f$ is a polynomial of degree no more than $n$.
